reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s treatment of unbounded linear views, where the argument leans on separability to infer that near-best futures require replicating highly value-efficient local configurations (“tiling”). That is a meaningful part of the essay’s case for fussiness, but it is not the whole case (the essay also argues for fragility via many independent dimensions and for fussiness across many bounded-view structures). Hence centrality is moderate.

The critique’s core point is plausible: if value is strongly holistic (e.g., depends on diversity/relations/global structure), then separability-style ‘tile the cosmos with the best module’ reasoning may fail, and the ‘hyper-efficiency narrow target’ conclusion could weaken. However, it doesn’t show that (i) such holistic theories are common/plausible enough to overturn the essay’s “most plausible views are fussy” conclusion, or (ii) holism actually makes the target broad rather than just shifting what’s hard (e.g., achieving the right kind/degree of diversity could itself be a narrow target). It also doesn’t engage the essay’s other routes to fussiness. So its refutational strength is limited.

Most claims are broadly correct as a conditional objection, though it overstates by implying holism straightforwardly ‘dissolves’ narrow-target problems rather than potentially relocating them. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Holistic value undermines the assumption that optimal futures require uniform efficiency
